ticket.description: A "Re-send Voucher" button could be useful if a voucher recipient informs the voucher issuer that they have mislaid or deleted the original invitation.
ticket.summary: Re-send Voucher button in Guest Voucher table

ticket.description: If I pause an authenticated upload, then pause an upload of the same file using a voucher, and then: * try to resume the authenticated upload of the same file (whether I logged off before starting the upload using the voucher or not), I receive the warning "Invalid or missing email" for a valid email address * log off and try to resume the upload of the same file using the voucher, I get a popup "Message. There has been an error - please contact your administrator". Observed with Firefox 15.0 on Mac OSX 10.6.8.
ticket.summary: Errors after pausing authenticated upload followed by pausing upload using voucher

ticket.description: When canceling a Flash upload the temporary file on the server is not available/removed (standard PHP mechanism) and move_uploaded_file() will return FALSE. This is always (regardless of reason) logged on the server as an ERROR in www/fs_upload.php although in this case (and possibly others) it is normal behaviour. This might be improved by looking at the specific reason (see http://www.php.net/manual/en/features.file-upload.errors.php ). For now left as a known issue.
ticket.summary: A normal Flash upload cancel generates E_ERROR (file NOT moved)

ticket.description: During discussion it was unclear exactly why this would be an issue. Xander to clarify with Pine Security.
ticket.summary: Security audit: 2.6.2: Add an access check to the admin page

ticket.description:
"The cookies that hold the session id have to be secured with certain flags. The secure flag instructs the browser to only send a cookie over HTTPS requests. This helps to prevent interception of the session id."
This is a recommendation for PHP-setup (in the supplied php.ini sample config file) and left to the administrator to enforce or not depending on the setup. Suggested feature for after 1.5 (configurable like in SSP). Was already a known issue and candidate for hardening document.
; If your FileSender is only available over https (which it should be), enable ; the following to have secure session cookies ; ; session.cookie_secure = On ; session.cookie_httponly = On
See also ticket #758
For longer term, this would better be enforced by FileSender to prevent "shoot yourself in the foot". SimpleSAMLphp has this, and could possibly be copied.
ticket.summary: Security audit: 2.11.4: Set the secure flag on the session cookie using session_set_cookie_params().
Add sessionid to log data table

ticket.description: Use session variables to display an error message if users try to upload the same file in multiple tabs in the same browser. This leads to corrupt files arriving on other end. Needs to be displayed both for Flash and HTML5 upload cases. Needs to be done in "validate upload".
ticket.summary: Display error message when trying to upload same file in multipel tabs of same browser

ticket.description:
Jeff Hagley, setting up the Internet2 FileSender install, came with this feature request.
Implement real time feedback to the user through the UI on upload/download performance and feedback on that performance relative to what others get.
If we can tell a user "the average person got 80Mbps upload and 83 Mbps download, and here is what you just got/are getting" that would help both the user and the site.
The user has the benefit of knowing whether he's within the reasonable upload/downloadspeed band or whether there is something that might need attention.
The site has the benefit of both marketing a high speed high quality network "upload through your NREN and life is good", and enabling a user to figure out whether the problem is their bandwidth/desktop or whether there might be a service issue.
Blue sky dream: something a-la SURFnet-Detective for FileSender specific. Give users real time feedback on upload/download performance, and on said performance compared to other users. In addition, allow them to do a pre-upload check on performance. AdobeConnect does this, as do many DDoS clients. That pre-upload check might then include other checks, a sort of "can I do FileSender and how fast can I do it" check. Lastly would be great to include some way to help users diagnose possible problems.
Now this looks remarkably like the SURFnet detective but then FileSender specific.
It would require stuff in the UI. Where we'd put it is probably clear when we've sorted out the "where do we put advanced functionality without cluttering the basic functionality" question. In addition there is backend code that needs to be written.
Jeff suggested this could work with PerfSonar.
ticket.summary: Real time upload/download performance feedback

ticket.description: Users tend to cut&paste email addresses including the 'free form text' parts like: "Firstname Lastname" <user@example.org> Currenty these addresses are not accepted or handled very well.
ticket.summary: Accept and use "free form text" in email addresses
possible performance improvement in www/fs_upload.php

ticket.description: Current scripts created using Selenium-IDE work using the -htmlSuite option of Selenium Server (Selenium-RC), with Firefox (*firefox) and IE (*iexplore) (see #686). However this is not working with Google Chrome (*googlechrome), which requires further investigation.
ticket.summary: Investigate using selenium -htmlSuite with Google Chrome

ticket.description:
So far we made sure output that was the result of user input got sanitised. A recommendation in the May 2012 security audit is to apply output sanitisation to *all* possible output, making FileSender more hardened against unexpected consequences of changing language files, config files etc. and hardening better against unexpected avenues of attack.
This requires a systematic effort to go through *all* output generating functionality and:
-check whether output sanitisation is done -if not done, apply output sanitisation -verify that the most optimal output sanitisation function is applied for that particular context (place in workflow, point in time)
ticket.summary: Security audit 2.7.6: prevent shoot-in-foot, harden more by also sanitising output not user-generated

ticket.description:
Well-spotted by Vegard Polden.
We have a field "logtime" that is not used. It is only present in the database scripts:
scripts/filesender_db.sql: logtime time with time zone, scripts/mysql_filesender_db.sql: `logtime` time DEFAULT NULL,
Chris replies that this is deprecated. We one time planned to use separate fields for date and time but ended up using one field for both. So we have to get rid of that field.
-remove the field from both database scripts -add to upgrade notes some database command to remove that deprecated field from existing databases
All of course pending X acknowledge
ticket.summary: remove logtime from database scripts

ticket.description:
From the report:
"Issue: When the user can specify a filename, the application has to check if the filename does not contain unexpected values. For example, allowing a filename like ../file can lead to a "path traversal" problem.
Result: The Filesender application properly encodes user input before it is used within filenames. The following function could be improved, since it only replaces the first dot with an underscore, but all user input is hashed with md5 and therefore safe. This checklist item is marked as “Passed”."
Deferred because not currently an issue. For after 1.5: need to make a decision, either drop the function (in practice we use the hash where it matters) or fix it to prevent issues should we ever use the function for anything else. Client-side the browsers protect users against malicious-filenames-on-download.
ticket.summary: Security audit: 2.7.2: Change sanitizeFilename to filter out all bad characters

ticket.description: Is recommendation for PHP-setup. Suggested feature for after 1.5 (configurable like in SSP). See also 2.11.4. (#759)
ticket.summary: Security audit 2.11.5: Set the httponly flag on the session cookie using session_set_cookie_params().

ticket.description:
Recommendation: At moment of login, re-initialise all variables including php_sessionId to prevent session fixation.
Impact score in audit is low, not deemed directly dangerous for now. This requires more research and impact analysis, to be done post.1.5 release.
ticket.summary: Security audit 2.11.2: Use the session_regenerate_id function when the user logs in to prevent session fixation.

ticket.description: When adding multiple recipients to an existing file, the order of the resulting file listings is unexpected, with the two entries in separate parts of the table rather than together above the original file entry or at the top of the list.
ticket.summary: My FIles listing out of order when adding multiple recipients

ticket.description:
Thunderbird 13 offers the possiblitiy to use Filelink Services like yousendit.
http://filesender.uservoice.com/forums/56700-filesender-feature-request-forum
Feature suggested by Christoph Graf, Claude Tompers and Ronny Gudden.

ticket.description: There is an issue, (think french language file :), it needs to be fixed to prevent longer term issues but is not a blocking issue for beta release. Note though that if we release *with* this issue, we do need to document how Claude solved it.
ticket.summary: Handling single quotes in (new) language files

ticket.description: When requesting the index.php?s=complete and index.php?s=completev URL's (even when not authenticated or using a voucher) the page always displays that my file has been uploaded. Thiis should probably also be checked so that the normal login screen is displayed
ticket.summary: /index.php?s=complete and completev pages don't check for AuthN/voucher

ticket.description: Referring to the discussion in #699: when adding a user to a file, should that entry pop up right above the existing file, or should it popup "latest added first"? Having some logic sort options in the MyFiles table might be helpful in general. Note that also "how to display "multiple file uploads" will be an interesting one.
ticket.summary: add sort options to MyFiles table

ticket.description:
SimpleSamlphp throws up a feedback form whenever something "really bad" happens. The ease of reporting critical errors makes people actually report those. FileSender should have something like that. For example when a "$lang["_DISK_SPACE_ERROR"]" is thrown, that a pointer to the instances standard problem reporting mechanisms is included. Or even better: a standard form. Something like that.
This feature suggestion is to comb through the language file and identify logical points where to do that. Second stage is to implement a practical way to make user feedback easy but only when you as service admin *really* want it: when stuf unexpectedly has gone wrong. Maybe a standard feedback form or something.
ticket.summary: Facilitate feedback-points in warnings/errors

ticket.description: For the project PHP would be appropriate, however Python or Java may be considered as alternatives. Code selection is dependent on which are supported by Selenium, as well as which browsers the code drivers support. In consultation with all members of core development team. Once driver has been selected, export Selenium-IDE scripts for expansion and use with Selenium Server.
ticket.summary: Select Selenium Remote Control "driver" to export scripts from Selenium-IDE

ticket.description:
At the moment there is a problem when the default config.php is changed, the debian package process patches config.php to set default settings and if this file is changed the patch fails.
There are a number of solutions; * leave it as is; make the patch every time config.php changes * Split out config directives into separated files (DB config, location config, etc), this minimizes the chance of change collision * Include a complete copy of config.php in the debian package. Problem here is that if config.php is changed the debian version needs to be revised also.
Probably we will have the same problem for the RPM packages.
ticket.summary: optimizing config.php for distribution

ticket.description: Needs research, mainly on how to make the config entries 'relocatable'.
ticket.summary: Make RPM's relocatable

ticket.description: HTTP 1.1 supports persistent http connections. If we throw chunks over the same http connection rather than creating a new connection for each chunk we would save the tcp window size negotiated and that might improve upload performance on longer latency links. Note that we *might* already be doing this, I'm just not sure.
ticket.summary: Possible performance improvement: use persistent HTTP1.1 for file upload

ticket.description:
easiest upload is the "send to self". Implement an easy way for a user to see that by selecting a file and clicking send, they send the file to themselves.
Options: -make it implicit by just clicking on "send" with empty To: filed -prefill the To: field with the user's own address, or explicitly add it (non-changeable) at the end to indicate that a file will *always* be sent to a user self
ticket.summary: one-click simplest upload

ticket.description: Placeholder ticket, when downloading on an Android (2.2) phone two mails are sent and two downloads appear to be done.
ticket.summary: Double download with Android

ticket.description:
In many cases when users for whatever reason use the "back" button of the browser they will go back to a SimpleSAMLphp page which in most cases reults in an error page like: 
Exception: State information lost, and no way to restart the request.

0: /usr/share/simplesamlphp/lib/SimpleSAML/Auth/State.php:158 (SimpleSAML_Auth_State::loadState)
1: /usr/share/simplesamlphp/modules/saml/www/sp/saml2-acs.php:24 (require)
2: /usr/share/simplesamlphp/www/module.php:135 (N/A)

URL:
https://filesender.surfnet.nl/simplesaml/module.php/saml/sp/saml2-acs.php/default-sp
This is a common case when using SSP (not only with FileSender) and I'm not sure if it is fixable or where it should be 'fixed'. A few posibilities to handle this: - Disable the Back button (if possible but even when it is possible it looks intrusive/confusing to do that) - Leave it as is and make a FAQ entry - Do a 'redirect' from the/a first FileSender landing page to the 'New Upload' page so that when people do use the Back button they go back to a FileSender page and not a SSP page ? FYI: at SURFnet I almost get no support questions (it does seem to work without questions for most people) except for the occasional error report about this one. Jan also got them at UNINETT. My standard reply ("Don't use the Back button") somehow doesn't feel good ;-) It does happen in 1.0/1,1 but also in 1.5 if you never leave the New Upload page.
ticket.summary: Use of the "back" browser button gives SimpleSAMLphp error

ticket.description: When you start an upload between 23:00 and 24:00 on a day in 'wintertime' and the maximum expiry date is on a date after switching to summer time the shown and sent maximum expiry date will be one day off (later than the 'expected' day).
ticket.summary: Daylight savings time issue with server side based maximum expiry date

ticket.description:
Hi, the columns for ipv4 and ipv6 in database currently uses varchar data type. I think it would be nice to change it in some future release to more suitable integer types that would save some space (-->speed increase) and it would be also easier and faster to to some statistics (e.g. group by netmask).
Jiri Horky
ticket.summary: inefficient ipv4 and ipv6 data types in database

ticket.description:
I propose a structure for database updates:
* All database updates from all old versions to the latest version should be in a separated folder 'updates' * A user should call the correct database update file during upgrade * Maybe a check should be added if the correct update is ran (a version field in the database is required for this) * The user should always remove the update folder afterward * Optionally a check could be added that filesender wouldn't do anything if update folder is still there
ticket.summary: Database updates

ticket.description:
When a voucher user tries to use a voucher that either already has been used or has been cancelled, the error message should incorporate some details about the voucher we're talking about.
-who issued the voucher -when was it issued -what was its validity date
ticket.summary: Expand "this voucher has been used/cancelled" error report

ticket.description: When sending a file to an email list, all the download receipts are sent to the mailinglist as well: mail storm ensues. Right now the workaround is to tell people to send it to themselves first, and then to the email list. A more clever solution would be practical and could possibly be tied in to the group work?
ticket.summary: Email receipts: think of clever solution for "send file to group on mailinglist" problem

ticket.description:
Pause/resume of larger uploads is currently an unknown feature. Suggested features:
-Make it an explicitly available function by for example an explicit pause button during upload phase -Make it explicitly available when resuming-after-failure: "you appear to want to upload a file that you tried before. Resume or start fresh?"
ticket.summary: Improve user-feedback on use of pause/resume

ticket.description:
It might be useful to provide users with an unobtrusive per-file-opt-in mechanism that (provided they opt in) would provide them with notification of imminent expiry of a file -- they could use this notification event to take actions such as ringing their intended recipients in a last-ditch effort to get them to download the soon-to-be-no-longer-available file, or re-upload a new file or a replacement file.
Off the top of my head I could think of the attaching of an iCalendar TODO event along with the your-file-is-now-available email; users could decide for themselves whether to import the event in the iCalendar file into their personal calendars. Xander warns me that some groupware email clients (Zimbra?) automatically import such iCalendar files into their user calendars, without consulting the user.
More exotically, perhaps per-user-per-file RSS subscriptions are possible? Per-user tweets? Per-user facebook wall messages? Suggestions very welcome.
ticket.summary: provide opt-in mechanism to notify of imminent file expiry

ticket.description: Gmail labels filesender emails as "possible phishing". I assume this issue ties in with SPF records, preventing for example apple's mail client to label filesender emails as "spam" etc. So this is more of a placeholder ticket for holding the thought that making sure filesender emails get through isn't 100% wrapped up nicely.
ticket.summary: Get rid of "this email might be phishing" when sending to gmail accounts

ticket.description: Users have noticed that a file they upload needs to have a file extension. Is there a reason why an extension is required? Can this be an option that is either enabled or disabled in config.php?
ticket.summary: Upload should not require file extension

ticket.description: >> * if a file or voucher is selected from a table, the whole file’s row >> becomes highlighted in blue - this does not reset if I click elsewhere >> on the same page, but does reset if I go to another CloudStor function >> (e.g. click on the "New File" button then on the "Voucher" button >> again) and return. It would be nice if I could click off the voucher >> line somehow to deselect it.
ticket.summary: Enable deselect of selected values in file and voucher tables

ticket.description:
If you have more than two files, it becomes interesting to be able to apply the "re-send email" and especially "delete" action to multiple files at once. I don't know how this would pan out for "add recipient".
Envisaged result for user: -tickbox or other practical method to select which files to apply action to -give user a good way to indicate and *know* whatever will be done now will be applied to multiple files -ask "are you sure" -do action
Maybe a tickbox "whatever I will do now, will be applied to multiple files".
ticket.summary: Enable "apply action to multiple files" in MyFiles and Vouchers tables

ticket.description: It would be nice to have a configurable <title> for the various pages, perhaps one part configurable end another part context sensitive (i.e. dependent on where in the workflow you are, upload, download etc). Currently it is mostly hardcoded in the various sources with "Filesender:"
ticket.summary: UI: Configurable <title>

ticket.description:
One of the obvious issues with the emails that FileSender sends out is that users have become weary of mails that say 'download the cool file here!'. A way to make our emails somewhat more trustworthy is to digitally sign them. Note that this would be a longer term feature suggestion.
Possible ways of implementing this: http://www.cynergi.com/function-send-email-digital-signature-attachments-php.html http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1487680/signed-email-in-php/1491634
Before thinking of implementing it we would probably want to get some experience with signed emails using some signing email gateway.
ticket.summary: allow to send emails S/MIME signed [L]

ticket.description:
With version 1.5 we have a multi-language UI. The email templates are still one language. This might be a problem we can not solve.
How do you deal with a Norwegian user sending a file to a Brazilian user? The Brazilian might not want to receive a Norwegian email. A Norwegian email with "english at the bottom" might also not be desirable. Letting people set the language of the recipients sounds cumbersome and would be unwieldy with multiple recipients.
There is no widely deployed mechanism to let an email client pick a locale on behalf of the recipient.
So this problem appears to be a thorny one: we know who the *sender* is, but have no clue about the receiver. The user knows but shouldn't be bothered with questions about that and besides, allowing a user to set a certain attribute of a recipient stimulates the next desire: being able to store such information about recipients. We currently store no permanent information whatsoever and that makes the service very easy to run, which is a characteristic we should think carefully about before giving it up.
ticket.summary: Multi-language email templates [L]

ticket.description:
We're using the standard download functionality of browsers and the download manager of for example firefox supports pausing a download but not a download from FileSender 1.5. Safari doesn't support pause/resume downloads.
The question is -should we make FireFox's (and other browser's) pause/resume work or not? -should we go further and implement a more generic pause/resume mechanism and if so, why? -would we automatically get this if we implement "direct download link" functionality?
Too many unanswered questions and not enough user pressure to make this a first priority.
ticket.summary: Implement pause/resume for downloads

ticket.description:
We currently implement the explicit tickbox AuP method.
An alternative might be the implicit clickable link with "by using this service you agree to the AuP".
ticket.summary: Terms of Service / AUP link: legal requirements

ticket.description: Currently a voucher can be used exactly 1 time within the validity period. It should be possible to allow a voucher to be used X times.
ticket.summary: Allow voucher to be used multiple times

ticket.description: when the filestore is full, have an ability to overflow to another filestore. Example: own primary disk, is full, overflow to amazon's S3 until you upgrade your own primary disk store. Question would be where to do this: in the application or on the filesystem.
ticket.summary: multiple storage backend locations [xl]

ticket.description:
Use cases:
-allow access to FileSender functionality from webmail -access to FileSender from portal sites (think HPC web portals) -integration in scientific workflow
ticket.summary: Develop API to allow non-web access to FileSender functionality

ticket.description:
When a recipient clicks on the download link, a web page opens with info and a big download button. The original motivation for doing it this way was practical: we couldn't do direct downloads with the technology choices we'd made. However, this reason is no longer there.
In addition, back in the filesender prototyping days in 2008, I remember reasoning that a user ought to have both options: a direct download-link in the email, clicking on which resulted in the file downloading (and possibly opening in the right application), with in additoin a "click here to learn more about your file before downloading it" anti-phishing link.
We ended up with *only* the anti-phishing option, out of necessity. Now that it is no longer needed, we should revisit this and make it easier.
This ties in with a request I've seen for a "direct download link" to allow tools like wget, curl to download a file directly (automating workflow!). Another good reason to do this is complaints I got from a number of users: the click on the link but the file doesn't open in <relevant app>. So there is a group of users to whom it is more natural to click and see the file open. I suggest we make this happen.
It probably involves some fiddling with sending the right mime-type as well I'd guess.
ticket.summary: Improve download usability: direct download link + correct mime-type?

ticket.description:
When cancelling a file upload, all fields (To:, Subject, Message) are cleared. The assumption is someone would want to upload a new file. That behaviour is suboptimal if the only thing the user wants to do is *send a different file*. Seeing your possibly long message disappear might not be what you're waiting for.
Maybe we should drop the auto clear and make it very easy for a user to clear the form. In a way that's already there, they can press "new upload". So rather than auto-clear, maybe ask on cancel a question of the type "clear form, select new file or quit"?
Thank you NAKAMURA Motonori for bringing this up!
ticket.summary: Rethink "clear on cancel" in the Upload UI

ticket.description:
As suggested by Jonathan Van der Watt:
"The option to either search an address book, or have filesender search it automatically and display options as you type the email address... This would ease the entering of multiple email addresses for larger institutions who already maintain such an address book for their users."
ticket.summary: Addressbook search/integration

ticket.description:
With large files it takes time, especially on slower links, before the progress bar makes a 1% tick. It might be informative to have numerical progress as well, under the progress bar.
Something like "xxx of xxx bytes/kb/mb/GB transferred.
Implementing the counter probably is a good step towards a mechanism for doing realtime uploadspeed indicator in FileSender.
ticket.summary: Post-1.5: have numerical progress under progress bar

ticket.description: Make sure the file server-side is 100% identical to the file client side.
ticket.summary: CRC/Checksum to ensure file integrity

ticket.description: Change chunk size depending on file size to provide a smooth progress bar.
ticket.summary: Javascript/HTML5 upload chunk size to suit progress bar

ticket.description:
Today a feature request came in from Oslo University which appears to make sense. They would like an option to have a file become available for download *after a certain date+time*. Use cases: any information under embargo until a certain time. Like Call for Tender specs, like PhD thesis, etc.
This would have to wait until we have a good handle on the "how to present advanced functionality to only those users who want/need it without bothering those that don't".
ticket.summary: Allow for a "don't make file available until" date when uploading

ticket.description:
Some users have "computer fear". So while the FileSender UI is very self-explaining, some users need a little bit of assistance in first time use to allow them to overcome "first use fear".
What I imagine is that a first time user can have some "first use assistance" in the form of for example a little youtube video showing them how FileSender works (in their own language), and possibly a big help button. Something like that.
But this is UI clutter for those people who know quite well how to use it. So hence this ticket: I would like to make it possible that a first time user gets a slightly different UI experience then a second time user. This mechanism can be generalised to offer different groups different "help".
ticket.summary: Multiple User Interface views, guided use vs. normal use

ticket.description:
Yesterday I presented CloudStor to about 40 faculty-IT support at NTNU, Trondheim Uni. One of them came with the question whether it was possible, in MyFiles, to extend the expiry time of a file. Say you sent a file to someone, that someone turned out to be on holiday, then you might want to extend the expiry time.
Thoughts: treat this in the way libraries do? Allow for one (or more, such to be configurable) extension of the expiry date, presumably using a button "extend file availability period". Easiest would be if you would have a standard "file availability extension" period. That would be server-configurable as well, and presumably one week would be a good default. However, you can see coming that people would want to just pick a particular date: "I *know* the person will be back on that and that date, so that date + 1 week is good."
This then implies both a button "extend" which does a standard extension plus a calendar which allows a user to set a more specific date. The date box would need to be there anyway to show when the file is about to expire. Having said that, there still ought to be a max expire, also on "extension of availability". By far the easiest way to get started with this appears to be a simple button "extend availability" that simply extends availability with a configurable standard amount of time/days and not let the user pick something.
ticket.summary: Enable expiry time extension

ticket.description:
The concrete use case that triggered this is when someone sends a large file to a mailing list. The receipt email "person X has downloaded file Y" is sent *to* the uploader with a Cc: to the *downloader/recipient*. If the recipient is an email list, the Cc: will go to the email list for every download. If you distribute a file to a list with several 100 people, that is a bit .. annoying.
The difficulty here is to cater for use cases like this without complicating the user interface. A solution might be to have different "filesender user views" depending on which "persona" you are. Using personas is a common technique in user interaction design. You define a limited number of persons with certain characteristics as the people you imagine will use the software and cater to their needs.
For FileSender this might be: a first time user, someone who uses the functionality "as is" and someone who considers him/herself as a "power user" and wants to be able to tweak more of the experience. The first time user would for example have access to a more "guided" approach, a "as is" user knows how to use FileSender but needs no advanced functionality nor does he want to be bothered with the "guided use". The power user would have the option to switch stuff on and off.
This would lead to 3 views on the functionality.
I am tempted to think we need to go that way, as we also need to figure out how to incorporate for example time stamping in the UI.
This requires more thought and more speccing, but at least it is a ticket now....
ticket.summary: Allow uploader to disable download receipt email to file *recipient*

ticket.description:
The SURFnet Office IdP replaces the normal SP logout page with a strong security advice when logging out of a service like FileSender. This should warn users that logging out of one specific service doesn't terminate other sessions one might have to other services and also doesn't clear the 'main' session with the identity provider of the user. This makes it possible to login again to FileSender without being asked for credentials. We might want to add a warning about this to the FileSender logout page.
The (a bit technical) text from the SURFet IdP as example: ------------- Due to the nature of this centralized authentication infrastructure and the type of sessions that you have running, it not possible to terminate all of your sessions with each Service Provider with 100% certainty. There is only one option for guaranteed secure logout:
Shutdown your browser when you want to end your running sessions in a secure way!
Apologies for the inconvenience: this is a strong security advice. -------------
Suggestion from Wendy: "Your logout from FileSender is complete. To ensure you have also been logged out from your institutional identity provider, please quit your browser."
Possible bears on the road: - does this cover all cases ? (is every logon to FileSender 'federative'? How about a local u/p database setup?
ticket.summary: Logout warning about still existing 'IdP sessions'

ticket.description: Expanding on ##340 about email address validation it would be good to be able to accept email addresses in various forms, to match what people get from their email clients. That means doing "guessing" of what people mean while refusing plain bad addresses. Make sure that email addresses containing internationalised characters can be used. This requires a proper writeup of what we want to do with email address input!
ticket.summary: Email address guessing and refusing bad addresses

ticket.description: Integration with timestamping to allow use for, for example, handing in student assignments where time of delivery is important.
ticket.summary: integration with timestamping

ticket.description: Logging is done at two places at the moment. Logging goes into log files and logging goes into a database. I would say that both are needed. Logging to log files makes it easy for a sysadmin to investigate faults in the service. Logging to the database means that a service manager can easily generate custom reports and stats without bothering the sysadmin. But, this needs a thorough rethink for 2.0 so we have some solid and consistent thinking behind our logging mechanism: clear goals for what needs to be achieved that will lead to a clear implementation of logging and loglevels as well as what is logged where (when).
ticket.summary: Overhaul log mechanism

ticket.description: Make things such that you can hook multiple identity providers onto FileSender and have a different attribute mapping for each IdP
ticket.summary: Make the IdP attribute mapping configurable when using multiple IdPs

ticket.description: use the existing chunking mechanism provided by the gears plugin to parallelise uploads -- upload multiple chunks simultaneously, using separate http sessions (and consequently tcp streams) so upload on suboptimally tuned machines is improved
ticket.summary: parallelise upload / download

ticket.description: number indicating transferspeed next to progress bar (or something similar)
ticket.summary: interface: upload speed indicator (Mbps)

ticket.description: >> * In the My Files table, at least some of the text in the columns do not >> wrap, and perhaps the column widths could be adjusted, and it might make >> sense to move the “Created” column to before the “Expiry” column (i.e. >> chronological order)
ticket.summary: look at column widths and order in MyFiles tab
